children.subject:
Come talk to us about it at the class tomorrow! In general, having one of the prereqs is helpful, but depending on your experiences and interests and whatnot, it might be possible to make it work.

As for whether or not it's offered every semester - the past sessions have only been offered in the spring. Since this is a 'special topics' course, there's no 100% guarantee that it will be offered regularly.
Is this usually offered every semester? Because I'm absolutely interested, but I won't have any of the pre-reqs until after this semester.

history.content:
EE194 - 28nm SoC for IoT
TuTh 4pm-5:30pm, 299 Cory
Instructors: Edward Wang, Kris Pister

Pre-requisites: one of either EECS 151 (Digital Systems), EE 140
(Analog Integrated Circuits), or EE 142 (Integrated Circuits for
Communication) or relevant research/project experience

Course website: http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee290c/sp19/

Great for undergraduates who have taken one of analog/RF/digital
design and interest in applying said knowledge to a real IC project.

The (ambitious) goal is to send a chip out for fabrication in 28 nm

CMOS with a RISC-V processor and Bluetooth radio. Teams of
students will work together to design and integrate the modules into a
single chip.  Topics include: Analog/RF/digital mixed-signal ASIC
toolchain: layout, synthesis, extraction, verification; design for
test; system modeling; interface design; floorplanning; system
simulation.

The class is intended for advanced undergraduates and graduate
students in EECS. Please feel free to contact one of the instructors
if you need additional information.
history.subject: EE194 28 nm SoC for IoT - the tapeout class
